text: Revenues - Up 12% YoY, up 6% ex-divestiture-related impacts as strength across Services, Fixed Income and USPB was partially offset by Banking, Equity Markets and Wealth as well as reductions from the exits and wind-downs.
reference:
Slide Text
Citigroup, Q1, 2023, Earnings Call Presentation, Slide 3

text: Expenses - Up 1% YoY, up 5% ex-divestiture-related impacts, largely driven by investments in transformation, other risk & controls and inflation, partially offset by productivity savings and expense reductions from the exits and wind-downs.

Slide Text
Citigroup, Q1, 2023, Earnings Call Presentation, Slide 3

text: Credit Costs – Cost of $2.0 billion, primarily driven by the continued normalization in Card NCLs and an ACL build primarily due to macroeconomic assumptions and card revolving balance growth.

Citigroup, Q1, 2023, Earnings Call Presentation, Slide 3

text: Structural / Other factors contributed a ~4% increase to expenses, driven by other risk & control initiatives, inflation, and severance, partially offset by productivity savings and exit market reductions.

Slide Text

text: Added ~8k people in Technology; total technology-related spend up 12% YoY.
reference:
Slide Text
Citigroup, Q1, 2023, Earnings Call Presentation, Slide 3

text: By enhancing and modernizing our infrastructure, we are creating new products, improving our existing capabilities and risk & controls, while generating efficiencies that will self-fund future investments.
reference:
Slide Text
Citigroup, Q1, 2023, Earnings Call Presentation, Slide 4

text: Platform & Process Simplification is reducing complexity and risk through strategic platforms like consolidating sanctions-screening platforms, retiring legacy trading platforms, and moving loan servicing to a single strategic platform.
reference:
Slide Text
Citigroup, Q1, 2023, Earnings Call Presentation, Slide 4

text: Security & Infrastructure Modernization is increasing security, efficiency & scalability by enhancing cybersecurity with AI, building secure cloud capabilities, and leveraging cloud-based solutions to streamline ledger connectivity.

Citigroup, Q1, 2023, Earnings Call Presentation, Slide 4

text: The company is well capitalized with a CET1 Capital ratio of 13.4%, which is 140bps above the 1Q23 regulatory requirement.

text: Regulatory requirements increased to 11.5% in October 2022 due to an increase in the Stress Capital Buffer, and to 12% in January 2023 due to an increase in the G-SIB surcharge.

text: Our Vision is to be the preeminent banking partner for institutions with cross-border needs, a global leader in wealth management, and a valued personal bank in our home market.

text: As proposed, the U.S. B3E NPR increases the Firm's RWA by 30% ($500B) and required capital by 25% ($50B).
reference:
Slide Text
JPMorgan, Q3, 2023, Earnings Call Presentation, Slide 4

text: $22.5B of the increase is directly linked to the firm's 4.5% GSIB surcharge (4.5% x $500B), despite no change in the systemic risk footprint.
reference:
Slide Text
JPMorgan, Q3, 2023, Earnings Call Presentation, Slide 4

text: The proposal increases the required capital for operational risk by $30B.
reference:
Slide Text
JPMorgan, Q3, 2023, Earnings Call Presentation, Slide 4

text: The firm estimates its SCB already includes ~$15B capital for operational risk.
reference:
Slide Text
JPMorgan, Q3, 2023, Earnings Call Presentation, Slide 4

text: JPM believes that an RWA change of this magnitude requires corresponding adjustments to SCB and GSIB.
reference:
Slide Text
JPMorgan, Q3, 2023, Earnings Call Presentation, Slide 4

text: Measured since the 2017 rules, JPM's CET1 capital requirements will have increased by ~45% should the rule be enacted as proposed.
reference:
Slide Text
JPMorgan, Q3, 2023, Earnings Call Presentation, Slide 4

text: Looking beyond the B3E proposal, the future trend for capital requirements is upward.
reference:
Slide Text
JPMorgan, Q3, 2023, Earnings Call Presentation, Slide 4

text: The firm anticipates that the Fed's incorporation of CECL in the stress test will raise the SCB.
reference:
Slide Text
JPMorgan, Q3, 2023, Earnings Call Presentation, Slide 4

text: Since the GSIB proposal did not adjust for growth, continued headwinds are expected due to ordinary economic growth.
reference:
Slide Text
JPMorgan, Q3, 2023, Earnings Call Presentation, Slide 4

text: JPM disagrees with the cost-benefit analysis and believes that increases of this magnitude are unwarranted.
reference:
Slide Text
